Catalogue.Scope: Features, attributes, enumerations and feature-attribute bindings for the use in combination with Inland ENCs

Source.name: bENC Encoding Guide for Inland ENCs

DataDictionaryReference.Name: coverage available
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: continuous coverage of spatial objects is available within this area.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: no coverage available
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: an area containing no spatial objects.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Category of zone of confidence in data
DataDictionaryReference.Remark: The CATZOC attribute definitions are currently the subject of review and the results of this review will be promulgated as soon as possible in the S-57 Corrections Document. See the CATZOC Table in S-57 for the full table layout.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: zone of confidence U (data not assessed)
Compilation scale
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: The scale at which the data was originally compiled.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Depth range value 1
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: The minimum (shoalest) value of a depth range.
DataDictionaryReference.Remark: Where the area dries, the value is negative. The unit of measure is defined in the DUNI subfield of the DSPM record or in the DUNITS attribute of the M_UNIT meta object class, e.g., metre (m). The resolution is 0.1 m or 0.1 fm or 0.1 ft.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Depth range value 2
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: The maximum (deepest) value of a depth range.
DataDictionaryReference.Remark: Where the area dries, the value is negative. The unit of measure is defined in the DUNI subfield of the DSPM record or in the DUNITS attribute of the M_UNIT meta object class, e.g., metre (m). The resolution is 0.1 m or 0.1 fm or 0.1 ft.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Exposition of sounding
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: Indicates objects with a 'value of sounding' not within the range of depth of the surrounding depth area.
DataDictionaryReference.Remark: This attribute indicates objects with a 'value of sounding' not within the range of depth of the surrounding depth area. These objects could be a potential danger for navigation.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: within the range of depth of the surrounding depth area
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: the depth corresponds to the depth range of the surrounding depth area. i.e. the depth is not shoaler than the minimum depth of the surrounding depth area or deeper than the maximum depth of the surrounding depth area.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: shoaler than the range of depth of the surrounding depth area
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: the depth is shoaler than the minimum depth of the surrounding depth area.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: deeper than the range of depth of the surrounding depth area
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: the depth is deeper than the maximum depth of the surrounding depth area.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Information
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: Textual information about the object.
DataDictionaryReference.Remark: The textual information could be, for example, a list, a table or a text. This attribute should be used, for example, to hold the information that is shown on paper charts by cautionary and explanatory notes. No formatting of text is possible within INFORM. If formatted text is required, then the attribute TXTDSC must be used.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Object name
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: The individual name of an object.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Pictorial representation
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: Indicates whether a pictorial representation of the object is available.
DataDictionaryReference.Remark: The 'pictorial representation' could be a drawing or a photo. The string encodes the file name of an external graphic file (pixel/vector).

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Positional Accuracy
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: The best estimate of the accuracy of a position. The expected input is the maximum of the two-dimensional error. The error is assumed to be positive and negative. The plus/minus character shall not be encoded.
DataDictionaryReference.Remark: The unit of measure is defined in the PUNI subfield of the DSPM record, e.g., metre (m). The resolution is 0.1 m or 0.1 mm.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Publication reference
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: A reference to a nautical publication.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Quality of sounding measurement
DataDictionaryReference.Remark: The attribute 'quality of sounding measurement' indicates the reliability of the value of sounding.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: depth known
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: the depth from chart datum to the bottom is a known value.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: depth unknown
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: the depth from chart datum to the bottom is unknown.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: doubtful sounding
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: a depth that may be less than indicated. (adapted from IHO Dictionary, S-32, 5th Edition, 4840)

DataDictionaryReference.Name: unreliable sounding
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: a depth that is considered to be an unreliable value.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: no bottom found at value shown
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: upon investigation the bottom was not found at this depth. (adapted from IHO Dictionary, S-32, 5th Edition, 4848)

DataDictionaryReference.Name: least depth known
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: the shoalest depth over a feature is of known value. (adapted from IHO Dictionary, S-32, 5th Edition, 2705)

DataDictionaryReference.Name: least depth unknown, safe clearance at depth shown
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: the least depth over a feature is unknown, but there is considered to be safe clearance at this depth.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: value reported (not surveyed)
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: depth value obtained from a report, but not fully surveyed.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: value reported (not confirmed)
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: depth value obtained from a report, which it has not been possible to confirm.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: maintained depth
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: the depth at which a channel is kept by human influence, usually by dredging. (IHO Dictionary, S-32, 5th Edition, 3057)

DataDictionaryReference.Name: not regularly maintained
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: depths may be altered by human influence, but will not be routinely maintained.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Scale minimum
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: The minimum scale at which the object may be used e.g. for ECDIS presentation.
DataDictionaryReference.Remark: The modulus of the scale is indicated, that is 1:1 250 000 is encoded as 1250000.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Sounding accuracy
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: The best estimate of the accuracy of the sounding data. The maximum of the one-dimensional error. The error is assumed to be positive and negative. The plus/minus character shall not be encoded.
DataDictionaryReference.Remark: The unit of measure is defined in the DUNI subfield of the DSPM record or in the DUNITS attribute of the M_UNIT meta object class, e.g., metre (m). The resolution is 0.1 m or 0.1 fm or 0.1 ft.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Sounding distance - maximum
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: The maximum spacing of the principal sounding lines of a survey.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Sounding distance - minimum
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: The minimum spacing of the principal sounding lines of a survey.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Source date
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: The production date of the source, e.g. the date of measurement.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Source indication
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: Information about the source of the object.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Survey authority
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: The authority which was responsible for the survey.
DataDictionaryReference.Remark: The attribute 'survey authority' encodes the name of the source survey authority.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Survey date - end
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: The end date of the survey.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Survey date - start
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: The start date of the survey.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: reconnaissance / sketch survey
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: a survey made to a lower degree of accuracy and detail than the chosen scale would normally indicate.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: controlled survey
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: a thorough survey usually conducted with reference to guidelines.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: examintion survey
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: a survey principally aimed at the investigation of underwater obstructions and dangers.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: passage survey
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: a survey where soundings are acquired by vessels on passage.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: remotely sensed
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: a survey where features have been positioned and delimited using remote sensing techniques.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: found by echo-sounder
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: the depth was determined by using an instrument that determines depth of water by measuring the time interval between emission of a sonic or ultrasonic signal and return of its echo from the bottom. (adapted from IHO Dictionary, S-32, 1547)

DataDictionaryReference.Name: found by side-scan-sonar
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: the depth was computed from a record produced by active sonar in which fixed acoustic beams are directed into the water perpendicularly to the direction of travel to scan the bottom and generate a record of the bottom configuration. (adapted from IHO Dictionary, S-32, 4710)

DataDictionaryReference.Name: found by multi-beam
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: the depth was determined by using a wide swath echo sounder that uses multiple beams to measure depths directly below and transverse to the ship's track. (adapted from IHO Dictionary, S-32, 3339)

DataDictionaryReference.Name: found by diver
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: the depth was determined by a person skilled in the practice of diving. (adapted from IHO Dictionary, S-32, 1422)

DataDictionaryReference.Name: found by lead-line
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: the depth was determined by using a line, graduated with attached marks and fastened to a sounding lead. (adapted from IHO Dictionary, S-32, 2698)

DataDictionaryReference.Name: swept by wire-drag
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: the given area was determined to be free from navigational dangers to a certain depth by towing a buoyed wire at the desired depth by two launches, or a least depth was identified using the same technique. (adapted from IHO Dictionary, S-32, 5248, 6013)

DataDictionaryReference.Name: found by laser
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: the depth was determined by using an instrument that measures distance by emitting timed pulses of laser light and measuring the time between emission and reception of the reflected pulses. (adapted from IHO Dictionary, S-32, 2763)

DataDictionaryReference.Name: swept by vertical acoustic system
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: the given area has been swept using a system comprised of multiple echo sounder transducers attached to booms deployed from the survey vessel.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: found by electromagnetic sensor
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: the depth was determined by using an instrument that compares electromagnetic signals. (adapted from IHO Dictionary, S-32, 1571)

DataDictionaryReference.Name: photogrammetry
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: the depth was determined by applying mathematical techniques to photographs. (adapted from IHO Dictionary, S-32, 3791)

DataDictionaryReference.Name: satellite imagery
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: the depth was determined by using instruments placed aboard an artificial satellite. (adapted from IHO Dictionary, S-32, 4509)

DataDictionaryReference.Name: found by levelling
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: the depth was determined by using levelling techniques to find the elevation of the point relative to a datum. (adapted from IHO Dictionary, S-32, 2741)

DataDictionaryReference.Name: swept by side-scan-sonar
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: the given area was determined to be free from navigational dangers to a certain depth by towing a side-scan-sonar. (adapted from IHO Dictionary, S-32, 5248, 4710) [415.2]

DataDictionaryReference.Name: computer generated
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: the sounding was determined from a bottom model constructed using a computer.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Textual description
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: The string encodes the file name of an external text file that contains the text in English
DataDictionaryReference.Remark: The attribute 'textual description' indicates that a file containing text extracted from relevant pilot books or navigational publications is available.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Value of depth contour
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: The depth of a sea bottom contour.
DataDictionaryReference.Remark: Drying contours are indicated by a negative value. The unit of measure is defined in the DUNI subfield of the DSPM record or in the DUNITS attribute of the M_UNIT meta object class, e.g., metre (m). The resolution is 0.1 m or 0.1 fm or 0.1 ft.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Vertical datum
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: Vertical datum

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Mean low water springs
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: (MLWS) - the average height of the low waters of spring tides. Also called spring low water. (IHO Dictionary, S-32, 5th Edition, 3150)

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Mean lower low water springs
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: (MLLWS) - the average height of lower low water springs at a place. (IHO Dictionary, S-32, 5th Edition, 3146)

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Mean sea level
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: (MSL) - the average height of the surface of the sea at a tide station for all stages of the tide over a 19-year period, usually determined from hourly height readings measured from a fixed predetermined reference level. (IHO Dictionary, S-32, 5th Edition, 3156)

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Lowest low water
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: an arbitrary level conforming to the lowest tide observed at a place, or some what lower.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Mean low water
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: (MLW) - the average height of all low waters at a place over a 19-year period. (IHO Dictionary, S-32, 5th Edition, 3147)

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Lowest low water springs
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: an arbitrary level conforming to the lowest water level observed at a place at spring tides during a period of time shorter than 19 years. (Hydrographic Service, Royal Australian Navy)

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Approximate mean low water springs
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: an arbitrary level, usually within " 0.3m from that of mean low water springs (MLWS). (Hydrographic Service, Royal Australian Navy)

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Indian spring low water
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: (ISLW) - an arbitrary tidal datum approximating the level of the mean of the lower low water at spring tides. Also called Indian tidal plane. (IHO Dictionary, S-32, 5th Edition, 2427) A tidal datum approximating the lowest water level observed at a place, originated by G.H. Darwin for the tides of India at a level below MSL being equal to the sum of amplitudes of the harmonic constituents M2, S2, K1 and O1; usually below that of the lower low water at spring tides. Also called Indian tide plane. (Hydrographic Service, Royal Australian Navy).

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Low water springs
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: an arbitrary level, approximating that of mean low water springs (MLWS). (Hydrographic Service, Royal Australian Navy)

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Approximate lowest astronomical tide
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: an arbitrary level, usually within " 0.3m from that of lowest astronomical tide (LAT). (Hydrographic Service, Royal Australian Navy)

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Nearly lowest low water
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: an arbitrary level approximating the lowest water level observed at a place, usually equivalent to the Indian spring low water (ISLW). (Hydrographic Service, Royal Australian Navy)

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Mean lower low water
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: (MLLW) - the average height of the lower low waters at a place over a 19-year period. (IHO Dictionary, S-32, 5th Edition, 3145)

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Low water
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: an approximation of mean low water adopted as the reference level for a limited area, irrespective of better determinations at a later date. Used mostly in harbour and river engineering. Used in inland (non-tidal) waters. It is generally defined as a level which the daily mean water level would fall below less than 5% of the time and by no more than 0.2 metres during the navigation season. A single level surface is usually chosen as the low water datum for a whole lake. On a river, low water datum is a sloping surface which approximates the river surface at a low state. (Canadian Hydrographic Service)

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Approximate mean low water
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: an arbitrary level, usually within " 0.3m from that of mean low water (MLW). (Hydrographic Service, Royal Australian Navy)

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Approximate mean lower low water
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: an arbitrary level, usually within " 0.3m from that of mean lower low water (MLLW). (Hydrographic Service, Royal Australian Navy)

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Mean high water
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: (MHW) - the average height of all high waters at a place over a 19-year period. (IHO Dictionary, S-32, 5th Edition, 3141)

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Mean high water springs
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: (MHWS) - the average height of the high waters of spring tides. Also called spring high water. (IHO Dictionary, S-32, 5th Edition, 3144)

DataDictionaryReference.Name: High water
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: the highest level reached at a place by the water surface in one tidal cycle. Also called high tide. (IHO Dictionary, S-32, 5th Edition, 2251) when used on inland (non-tidal) waters it is generally defined as a level which the daily mean water level exceeds less than 5% of the time.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Approximate mean sea level
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: an arbitrary level, usually within " 0.3m from that of mean sea level (MSL). (Hydrographic Service, Royal Australian Navy)

DataDictionaryReference.Name: High water springs
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: an arbitrary level, approximating that of mean high water springs (MHWS). (Hydrographic Service, Royal Australian Navy)

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Mean higher high water
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: (MHHW) - the average height of higher high waters at a place over a 19-year period. (IHO Dictionary, S-32, 5th Edition, 3140)

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Equinoctial spring low water
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: the level of low water springs near the time of an equinox.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Lowest astronomical tide
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: (LAT) - the lowest tide level which can be predicted to occur under average meterological conditions and under any combination of astronomical conditions. (IHO Dictionary, S-32, 5th Edition, 2936)

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Local datum
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: an arbitrary datum defined by a local harbour authority, from which levels and tidal heights are measured by this authority.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: International Great Lakes Datum 1985
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: (IGLD 1985) - a vertical reference system with its zero based on the mean water level at Rimouski/Pointe-au-Pere, Quebec, over the period 1970 to 1988.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Mean water level
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: the average of all hourly water levels over the available period of record.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Lower low water large tide
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: (LLWLT) - the average of the lowest low waters, one from each of 19 years of observations.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Higher high water large tide
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: (HHWLT) - the average of the highest high waters, one from each of 19 years of observations.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Nearly highest high water
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: an arbitrary level approximating the highest water level observed at a place, usually equivalent to the high water springs.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Highest astronomical tide (HAT)
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: the highest tidal level which can be predicted to occur under average meteorological conditions and under any combination of astronomical conditions. (IHO Dictionary, S-32, 5th Edition, 2244).

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Information in national language
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: Textual information in national language characters
DataDictionaryReference.Remark: The attribute 'information in national language' encodes any textual information about an object using a specified national language. The textual information could be, for example, a list, a table or a text. This attribute should be used, for example, to hold the information that is shown on paper charts by cautionary and explanatory notes.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Object name in national language
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: Name of object in national language characters
DataDictionaryReference.Remark: The attribute 'object name in national language' encodes the individual name of an object in the specified national language.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Textual description in national language
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: The file name of an external text file that contains the text in a national language.
DataDictionaryReference.Remark: The attribute 'textual description in national language' indicates whether a text file containing text extracted from relevant pilot books or navigational publications is available.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: surveyed
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: the position(s) was(were) determined by the operation of making measurements for determining the relative position of points on, above or beneath the earth=s surface. Survey implies a regular, controlled survey of any date. (adapted from IHO Dictionary, S-32, 5195, and IHO Chart Specifications, M-4, 175.2)

DataDictionaryReference.Name: unsurveyed
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: survey data is does not exist or is very poor. (adapted from IHO Dictionary, S-32, 5732)

DataDictionaryReference.Name: inadequately surveyed
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: position data is of a very poor quality. (adapted from IHO Dictionary, S-32, 5732)

DataDictionaryReference.Name: approximated
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: a position that is considered to be less than third-order accuracy, but is generally considered to be within 30.5 metres of its correct geographic location. Also may apply to an object whose position does not remain fixed. (adapted from IHO Dictionary, S-32, 213, 3967, and IHO Specifications, M-4, 424.1)

DataDictionaryReference.Name: position doubtful
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: an object whose position has been reported but which is considered to be doubtful.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: unreliable
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: an object=s position obtained from questionable or unreliable data.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: reported (not confirmed)
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: an object whose position has been reported and its position confirmed by some means other than a formal survey such as an independent report of the same object.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: estimated
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: the most probable position of an object determined from incomplete data or data of questionable accuracy. (adapted from IHO Dictionary, S-32, 3960)

DataDictionaryReference.Name: precisely known
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: a position that is of a known value, such as the position of an anchor berth or other defined object.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: calculated
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: a position that is computed from data.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Vertical datum
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: Vertical datum

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Mean lower low water
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: (MLLW) - the average height of the lower low waters at a place over a 19-year period. (IHO Dictionary, S-32, 5th Edition, 3145)

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Local low water reference level
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: low water reference level of the local area

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Local high water reference level
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: high water reference level of the local area

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Local mean water reference level
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: mean water reference level of the local area

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Equivalent height of water (German GlW)
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: A low water level which is the result of a defined low water discharge - called "equivalent discharge".
DataDictionaryReference.Remark: A new agreement upon the value of the "equivalent discharge" is made every 10 years by the "Central Commission for Navigation on the Rhine". On average the "equivalent height of water" is currently fallen short of only at about 10 days per year [2002]

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Highest Shipping Height of Water (German HSW)
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: upper limit of water levels where navigation is allowed

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Reference low water level according to Danube Commission
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: The water level at a discharge, which is exceeded 94 % of the year within a period of 30 years.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Highest shipping height of water according to Danube Commission
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: The water level at a discharge, which is exceeded 1 % of the year within a period of 30 years.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Dutch river low water reference level (OLR)
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: The water level at a discharge, which is exceeded 95 % of the year within a period of 20 years.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Russian project water level
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: Conditional low water level with established probability (Hydrographic Terminology Dictionary, HDNO, 1984).

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Russian normal backwater level
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: Highest water level derived from the upper backwater stream in watercourse or reservoir under the normal operational conditions. (Hydrographic Terminology Dictionary, HDNO, 1984).

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Waterway distance
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: The distance measured from an origin of a river or canal

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Height/length units
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: Units of measure of waterway distances

DataDictionaryReference.Name: metres
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: heights/lengths are specified in metres (SI units of length)

DataDictionaryReference.Name: feet
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: heights/lengths are specified in feet (imperial units of length)

DataDictionaryReference.Name: kilometres
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: heights/lengths are specified in kilometres (1000 metres)

DataDictionaryReference.Name: hectometres
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: heights/lengths are specified in hectometres (100 metres)

DataDictionaryReference.Name: statute miles
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: heights/lengths are specified in statue (land) miles

DataDictionaryReference.Name: nautical miles
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: heights/lengths are specified in nautical (sea) miles

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Depth area
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: A depth area is a water area whose depth is within a defined range of values.
DataDictionaryReference.Remark: Intertidal areas are encoded as depth areas. These do not have to include soundings. The depth range within a depth area is defined by the attributes 'DRVAL1' and 'DRVAL2'.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Depth contour
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: A line connecting points of equal water depth which is sometimes significantly displaced outside of soundings, symbols and other chart detail for clarity as well as generalization. Depth contours, therefore, often represent an approximate location of the line of equal depth as related to the surveyed line delineated on the source. Also referred to as depth curve. (IHO Dictionary, S-32, 5th Edition, 1314, 1315)
DataDictionaryReference.Remark: Drying contours are encoded with negative values.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Dredged area
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: An area of the bottom of a body of water which has been deepened by dredging. (IHO Dictionary, S-32, 5th Edition, 1462)

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Sounding
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: A measured water depth or spot which has been reduced to a vertical datum (may be a drying height).
DataDictionaryReference.Remark: The value of the sounding is encoded in the 3-D Coordinate field of the Spatial Record Structure (see S-57 Part 3). Drying heights (drying soundings) are indicated by a negative value.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Unsurveyed area
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: An area for which no bathymetric survey information is available.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Accuracy of data
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: An area within which the best estimate of the overall accuracy of the data is uniform. The overall accuracy takes into account for example the source accuracy, chart scale, digitising accuracy etc..

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Compilation scale of data
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: An area within which the data was originally compiled at a uniform scale. For example, it may define the scale of the paper chart from which the data was digitised.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Coverage
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: A geographical area that describes the coverage and extent of spatial objects.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Nautical publication information
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: Used to relate additional nautical information or publications to the data.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Quality of data
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: An area within which a uniform assessment of the quality of the data exists.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Sounding datum
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: An area of uniform sounding datum.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Survey reliability
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: An area within which a uniform assessment of the reliability of source survey information exists.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Depth area
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: A depth area is a water area whose depth is within a defined range of values.
DataDictionaryReference.Remark: Intertidal areas are encoded as depth areas. These do not have to include soundings. The depth range within a depth area is defined by the attributes 'DRVAL1' and 'DRVAL2'.

DataDictionaryReference.Name: Sounding datum
DataDictionaryReference.Definition: An area of uniform sounding datum.
